qas.question: What is separated from the cellulose fibres?
What type of paper is paper made from chemical pulps known as?
What percentage of fibres are wasted in the bleaching process?
What percentage of cotton is cellulose?
What is separated from pulp to make wood?
What is wood dissolved in to get clean from cellulose?
What is combined with cellulose fibers when making pulp?
What is combined with lignin when making pulp?
When separating lignin from cellulose fibers, what is cooking oil dissolved in?
What is combined with the cellulose fibres?
What type of paper is wood made from chemical pulps known as?
What percentage of fibres are used in the bleaching process?
What percentage of cotton is not cellulose?

context: To make pulp from wood, a chemical pulping process separates <a0_0><b4_0><b6_0><b9_0>lignin<b9_0/><b6_0/><a0_0/> from <b7_0>cellulose fibres<b7_0/><b4_0/>. This is accomplished by dissolving <b8_0>lignin<b8_0/> in a <b5_0>cooking liquor<b5_0/>, so that it may be washed from the cellulose; this preserves the length of the cellulose fibres. Paper made from chemical pulps are also known as <a1_0><b10_0>wood-free<b10_0/><a1_0/> papers–not to be confused with tree-free paper; this is because they do not contain lignin, which deteriorates over time. The pulp can also be bleached to produce white paper, but this consumes <a2_0><b11_0>5%<b11_0/><a2_0/> of the fibres; chemical pulping processes are not used to make paper made from cotton, which is already <a3_0><b12_0>90<b12_0/>%<a3_0/> cellulose.
